docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson Food column on preparing risotto dishes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: RISOTTO is not a sensible dish for a large dinner party. It cannot be made in advance or left to simmer on the stove while the cook chats with guests. For family or even a couple of friends it is another matter, and I find it particularly appealing in the spring. One of my favorite recipes is made with fresh wild mushrooms and dried porcini. The dish is rich and satisfying, the porcini soaking liquid added to the rice intensifying the woodsy flavor.

docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson Food column on preparing cabbage; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: GREEN CABBAGE is coming into its peak season. But it is often overlooked in favor of more glamorous out-of-season vegetables, which cost more than twice the price. It is a pity, because it can be one of the most delicious vegetables when imaginatively prepared (when it is not boiled into oblivion). The two most common kinds on the market (apart from Chinese cabbages) are the crinkly dark green savoy cabbage and the familiar pale, smooth green cabbages with tightly wrapped leaves, which become almost translucent when cooked. Savoy cabbage is particularly good with game like pheasant or squab, flavored with bacon, white wine and chicken stock. Cabbage also goes well with rich fish like salmon or tuna. The celebrated French chef Joel Robuchon cooks cabbage with butter and cream and serves it under fillets of salmon with a white wine and sherry vinegar sauce. On a humbler level, one of my favorite cabbage dishes is colcannon, which my Irish grandmother used to make when I was a child. It consists of leftover mashed potatoes and cabbage sauteed in butter like a pancake. We often had it with cold chicken or ham for Sunday supper.

docs.lead_paragraph: FRESH tuna is best cooked rare or medium rare so it remains moist and juicy inside. If leftover tuna is recooked, the rosy interior blush will fade. But in recipes that incorporate strong seasonings as well as ingredients that contribute their moistness, cooked fresh tuna can be used successfully.

docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant food column offers advice on preparing late-summer vegetables; chicken and corn recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE main components for an easy late-summer menu await at the produce stand. Fresh corn on the cob, purple Italian prune plums, tomatoes and fresh herbs inspire the main course and dessert. The logistics are simple. A chicken starts on the grill, which can remain lighted to handle the corn shortly after the chicken goes into the oven. And, like the chicken, the corn can wait a bit before being served. It can even be kept warm in the slow oven with the chicken. Once the chicken comes out of the oven the temperature can be increased and the plums, prepared in their baking dish, can go in.

headline.main: Combining Grill and Oven for Preparing Late-Summer Fare

docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant column (Food) offers recipes for breakfast treats containing blueberries; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: OF all the abundant berries in season right now, blueberries are the best ones for breakfast. They are easy to add to a bowl of cereal or fold into pancake batter and, because they are delicious with maple syrup, they are excellent to warm with the syrup to top pancakes or waffles. And they are ideal for making quick muffins or scones, ready to come out of the oven and go to the table, still warm, for a festive weekend breakfast. Blueberry Bran Muffins Total time: 50 minutes 1/2 cup soft unsalted butter (1 stick), plus butter for pans if needed 3/4 cup 100 percent bran cereal (not flakes) 1 cup whole-wheat flour 3/4 cup all-purpose flour 2 teaspoons baking powder 1 teaspoon baking soda 1 teaspoon cinnamon 1/2 cup, packed, light brown sugar 2 eggs 2/3 cup plain yogurt 1 1/2 cups fresh blueberries. 1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. Butter 12 two-and-a-half-inch muffin cups or line them with fluted paper. 2. Combine the bran cereal, whole- wheat flour, all-purpose flour, baking powder, baking soda and cinnamon in a bowl and stir to blend the ingredients. Set aside. 3. Beat the butter until it is creamy and beat in the brown sugar. Stir in the eggs one at a time, then add one-third of the flour mixture. Stir in half the yogurt, then repeat with another third of the flour mixture, the remaining yogurt and the remaining flour mixture. Fold in the blueberries. 4. Spoon the batter into the muffin cups. They should not be quite filled. 5. Bake until the tops are firm to the touch and lightly browned, about 35 minutes. Yield: 12 muffins. Blueberry Corn Muffins Total time: 45 minutes 2 to 3 tablespoons melted butter 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour 1/2 cup yellow cornmeal 1 tablespoon baking powder 1 teaspoon cinnamon 1/2 teaspoon salt 1/2 cup plus 1 tablespoon sugar 2/3 cup milk 1 egg, lightly beaten 1 teaspoon vanilla extract 1 1/4 cups blueberries. 1. Preheat oven to 400 degrees. Use a tablespoon of the melted butter to grease 12 two-and-a-half-inch muffin tins, or fit them with fluted paper liners. 2. Mix the flour, cornmeal, baking powder, three-fourths teaspoon of the cinnamon, salt and half a cup of sugar together in a bowl. 3. Mix the milk, egg and vanilla together and stir into the dry ingredients just until the ingredients are moistened. Stir in the melted butter. Lightly mix in the blueberries. 4. Spoon the batter into the prepared muffin tins until the tins are nearly filled to the top. Combine the remaining sugar and cinnamon and sprinkle on the tops of the muffins. 5. Put in the oven and bake until the muffins have risen in peaks over the tops of the tins and are lightly browned, about 20 minutes. Cool briefly before serving. Yield: 12 muffins. Blueberry Scones Total time: 40 minutes 1 1/2 cups flour 2 teaspoons baking powder 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/4 teaspoon nutmeg 4 tablespoons cold butter, in pieces 2 tablespoons light brown sugar 1 egg 1/2 cup plus 1 tablespoon milk 3/4 cup blueberries. 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees. 2. Combine the flour, baking powder, salt and nutmeg in a bowl or in a food processor and mix or process briefly to blend the ingredients. Cut in the butter with a pastry blender or two knives or, by machine, by pulsing quickly, just until the mixture looks mealy. 3. Stir in the brown sugar. If you used a food processor, transfer the mixture to a bowl before adding the brown sugar by hand. Mix the egg with the half cup of milk and, with a fork, lightly mix the liquid into the dry ingredients to form a soft dough. 4. Transfer the dough to a lightly floured board, flatten it and top it with the blueberries. Gently knead the dough a few times to incorporate the blueberries, taking care not to squash the berries. Add a little more flour if necessary. 5. Once the berries have been incorporated, pat the dough into a circle about seven inches in diameter and nearly an inch thick. Cut into eight wedges and brush each with the remaining milk. 6. Put the wedges about an inch apart on an ungreased baking sheet, preferably one that is not dark metal. Bake 15 to 18 minutes, until the scones have risen and are lightly browned. Remove from the oven and cool about 10 minutes before serving. Yield: 8 scones.

docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson column offers advice on using sorrel, which has lemony taste; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A FEW years ago I bought a small pot of sorrel and planted it outdoors. Now it threatens to take over the garden. The leaves, which have a tart, lemony taste, are at their peak right now for eating, but when sorrel plants start to blossom later in the summer, the leaves can become very bitter. A few raw young sorrel leaves will perk up a green salad, but they are mainly eaten after they have been cooked. Sorrel makes a sharp, smooth sauce, which provides a perfect foil for rich, fatty fish like salmon, shad or mackerel. The sauce is also good with grilled lamb or veal chops, with roast chicken or as a filling for omelettes. Sorrel and potato soup, with a little cream stirred in at the end, makes a refreshing first course for a summer dinner party.

headline.main: From Sauce to Soup, Ways to Use the Lemony Taste of Sorrel

docs.abstract: Moira Hodgson column on preparing Tuscan-style food; recipes; cartoon (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: WHY does food taste so much better in Italy? Perhaps it was the soft air and the beautiful Tuscan landscape, but on a recent trip, even the simplest dish -- a slice of bread dipped in olive oil and seasoned with a little sea salt, or a plate of wild boar salami -- seemed remarkable. In Florence I had dinner at Cibreo, one of the city's most interesting restaurants (the chef recently cooked at the Four Seasons in Manhattan). They do not serve pasta here, and there is no set menu. Instead, the young waiters and waitresses who are trendily dressed in black, draw a chair up to your table and reel off the dishes of the day. These are unusual, even rather startling: cold peas in olive oil, tomato aspic, corned pork sewn inside a pigskin ''hat,'' and a salad made with mussels and artichokes. Dinner was extremely good and very different from the usual Tuscan fare.

docs.abstract: Molly O'Neill (Food) column on increasing focus on food in motion pictures; recipes for dishes appearing in various films; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Until recently, people didn't eat on the silver screen. With the exceptions of that erotic scene in ''Tom Jones'' and the plot of ''Who Is Killing the Great Chefs of Europe?'' food figured in film about as prominently as dental floss. But in the last decade or so, the cinema has begun to pig out. Food has been both plot and motive. It has been both grand and sumptuous, poignant and deary, sexy and scary. In ''Babette's Feast,'' for example, a grand meal paid for a lifetime of kindness, while in ''La Grand Bouffe,'' a group of middle-age men decide to eat themselves to death. The dark magic of food was the theme of ''Like Water for Chocolate.'' And food came to symbolize deep familial love in ''Eat, Drink, Man, Woman.''

docs.abstract: Florence Fabricant column (Food) offers tips on uses for plum tomatoes; recipes; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: CLINGING to the last vestiges of Indian summer, the shopper picks up ripe plum tomatoes. A salad, perhaps, will satisfy the die-hards. But a casserole or a savory tart may be better. Whatever the recipe, those versatile, late-season, egg-shaped tomatoes are still available in abundance. If the ones you buy are not quite scarlet and tender enough, leave them out on the kitchen counter for several days. And if they still do not pass muster, try cutting them in half and roasting them for two hours in a 200-degree oven before using them in a sauce or in the casserole or savory tart. Because roasting them will cause them to shrink, you will have to use more tomatoes, three pounds before roasting for the casserole and about two pounds for the tart.

headline.main: Besides Salad, Plum Tomatoes Round Out Casserole and a Tart
